moves.1. d4 Nf6 2. Nf3: This move stops the e5's Budapest. Does it?
moves.2... e5: I can get something back for the pawn (if Nxe5) by Bb4+, d6, etc. Maybe.
moves.3. e3: White blunders with this move. Not easy to see why, but for sure, what happens if...
moves.3... e4: White loses a tempo reatreating the N, while I'll be able to defend e4 with d5. Wonderful.
moves.4. Nfd2 d5 5. c4: Natural and almost forced to develop without being squeezed in.
moves.5... Bb4: ? Not a particularly good idea, since I'll have to exchange this B with a WN.
moves.6. a3 Bxd2+ 7. Nxd2: Now my problem is easier to understand: after cxd5, I can't take it back with the N (or Nxe4), but Qxd5, Bc4 is bad. I can't allow that.
moves.7... Bg4: Trying to do sometihing more than c6. After cxd, cxd, White has a strong attack on the white diagonal (a4-e8) I must be aware of.
moves.8. Be2: Wonderful! I have another try... like...
moves.8... h5 9. Bxg4: ? Maybe better was h3, forcing me into the exchange. Anyway. This represent an unique opportunity to open the h column for my rook, and keep white distracted from d5.
moves.9... hxg4 10. O-O: ? Instead of attacking, castling just into the enemy's fire is a common mistake. Don't overestimate castling.
moves.11. g3: Practically forced. Now my attack will go on... on the h column, with the Q. If I could remove Nf6 from the board... Qxg4 will stop my plans. But I need my Q on h. So let's make the hard way.
moves.11... Qe6: Without the lsb, cxd just helps me. But my Q's journey proved very costly. See how.
moves.12. Qb3: b7 is threatened, and I should have played b6, and if Qb5+, c6. White needs more tempos to penetrate. But I let him in!
moves.12... Qf5: ONe move from a nasty mate threat. Go on, take my R!
moves.13. Qxb7: ...but I realized now that white doesn't have to take the R... after my Q is gone to h5, Qc8+, Qxc7+. I shield it with my N and everything should be ok.
moves.15... Ng4+ 16. Kh1: ...and here I "had" to break in somehow. I bet my life on it...
moves.16... Nxe3: Let's see. As a sac, Nxf2+ was more accurate.
moves.17. fxe3 Qe2: !? This lets again white with the choice to take both R (Qc8, QxRh8, or Qxa8). But it threatens mate on g2 all the same, so white has only one move.
moves.18. Rg1: How to go on? I could only see...
moves.18... h2: ...but this time, Qc8+, Ke7, QxRh8, hxRg1=Q+, KxQ, Qxe6+, Kg2, Qxd4... I'll look into it deeper later.
moves.19. Rf1: !? now white is a move from adding Rxf7+ to his possible threats! Is black dead???
moves.19... Rh3: ?? Qc8+ wins it. Say I played Rh5, please... :-)
moves.20. Qxd5: Preferring the check threat to the R.
moves.20... c6: Saving the R. I'm feeling busted.
moves.21. Qxf7+: Now I got the way to win. But Re1 must go out of there. Can you see it? No, not Qe1+ or Qd1+ (Re1 and back and forth).
moves.22... Kc7 23. Rf7+: Done! I was already sure my opponent didn't realized that by doing so, he gave me an one-move mate threat. If he doesn't mate me, I win!
moves.23... Nd7: Go on, take my R! Take my N with your and try to give a perpetual to me...
moves.24. Qxg7: ?? Overlooking the mate threat. Of course, after Qe1+, Nf1 would follow. So?
moves.25. Kxg2 h1=Q+ 26. Kf2 Rh2#: And that's all folks! Don't follow my examples, just have fun with them! :-)
